thread.title: Sneaker freaks move online

author: Caroline James
title: Sneaker freaks move online
text:
The New Yeezy sneaker release, designed by Kanye West and made by adidas is in demand from sneaker fans. Photo: Anna Kucera
Do your friends hound you for brand-name footwear every time you leave the country?
Alex Hsu's did, so he took assertive action.
We source in bulk, don't buy a pair or two to fulfil orders but bring shoes in by the thousands, which lowers our shipping costs as it is averaged out.
Alex Hsu On July 1 last year he launched The Next Pair so his friends would never have to pay Australian domestic retail prices again for their favourite sneaker shoe brands or feel gutted if Hsu couldn't squeeze their requested shoes in his bulging suitcases.
Alex Hsu, Ryan McClelland, Andrew Wong and Kris Hunt of The Next Pair. Photo: Supplied
The 30-something e-commerce veteran started Sonix Technology in 2007 to import and trade branded IT equipment including IBM and Cisco.
Advertisement Although it's still going today, Hsu says the cloud "sort of killed" demand for a B2B business focused on parts and equipment services so he knew he had to diversify.
Spotting a gap in the market
Alexandra Mills, chief executive of The Active. Photo: Supplied
On one of his six annual trips to the United States to see his girlfriend, the penny dropped.
"Shoes are so bulky so you can only buy so many pairs [when you travel overseas]," he says.
"But it sure hurts when you come home and see the same shoes for double the price and it was that light-bulb moment when I asked myself 'why not create an online shoe website that mirrored my existing IT business in terms of structure and model?
"I realised we could leverage our existing contracts and experience to build a business selling a commodity that is highly sought after and importantly that I had a real passion for."
He started approaching US manufacturers Converse, Asics, Nike and Vans about distributing via his Australian e-retailing start-up.
They agreed and using funding from Sonix and his parents, he spent late 2013 developing a website with secure transaction capabilities and made his initial stock orders.
Then he got his childhood friend Andrew Wong on board; "it was the perfect timing as I was travelling abroad a lot and needed someone I trusted on the ground" then asked high school mates Ryan McClelland and Kristopher Hunt to join the venture.
Last summer the school friends DIY updated their warehouse racking system in Gladesville, Sydney so it now has room for 15,000 pairs of shoes.
"We are not extremely social media savvy so the first three or four months were very slow and we're used to B2B where Google is all you need [to find your market] but have found B2C is a bit different and you do need to do more to assure people that you are really what you claim to be and that there is no catch."
With no marketing budget, the lifestyle shoe e-retailer recorded $650,000 turnover in 2014-2015, almost 70 per cent of which came in its final quarter.
Site visitations are growing monthly and via a broader range of brands, which Hsu says is encouraging.
Keeping prices down
Asked about his business model and how he can price less than his shop rivals with exactly the same shoes, Hsu says he's able to offer prices typically 10 to 20 per cent lower because as an independent e-tailer his business can parallel import and has no affiliation with the brands it supplies.
"That said, we do offer up to 30 per cent off if deals or promo codes are used and there are definitely shoes approximately 50 per cent off for models that have been superseded by the latest in-season product, or models that we can get good deals on.
"We are not bound by the minimum advertised price policies issued by brands when we import from our overseas suppliers.
"As an example Rebel Sport or The Athletes Foot do have contracts with Asics Australia, which means they source from Australian distribution and therefore have to sell at their RRP otherwise everyone would be outpricing one another.
"Additionally bricks and mortar stores have higher overheads, whether it be staff, shop fittings, rent in a high foot-traffic location and they have limited customers based on their proximity to the store unless they have an online presence, whereas we source from countries where RRPs are lower than that of Australia.
"We source in bulk, don't buy a pair or two to fulfil orders but bring shoes in by the thousands, which lowers our shipping costs as it is averaged out."
The year ahead will focus on developing supporting apps and improving the website.
"Looking longer term anything that comes in pairs – socks, headphones, etc – will be products we will explore.
"We do have competitors but no competitors doing exactly what we do."
Flash sales
Alexandra Mills is chief executive of The Active, a start-up that shares some market turf with The Next Pair.
Founded in 2014 so Aussie don't have to travel abroad to buy discounted branded sportswear products including shoes, Mills says the flash sales site is one of 14 businesses under parent company the Aussie Commerce umbrella.
"It launched because we saw this gap in our local market today," Mills says.
"There are a lot of fashion and home-wares brands adopting the flash sale business model but surprisingly not sports and outdoor adventure.
"It's essentially about positioning (these products). We are still very committed to stock under $100."
Mills says The Active has 200,000 customers on its database and turned over $3 million in 2014-2015. It plans to double revenue this financial year.
"There are others in the market such as Catch of the Day which do release flash stock but do not specialise like we do and therefore not able to offer every style and every colour so, no, no exact rivals.
"Our challenge is making those relationships with the big brands and the big retailers so we get the best clearance stock; that is going to be our ongoing challenge."
Bricks and mortar
Meanwhile, the bricks and mortar Aussie retail footwear industry continues to slide.
According to latest figures from global company IBISWorld, revenue has declined by 2.9 per cent a year since 2010 to $2.8 billion. It was expected to contract by 2.4 per cent in 2014-2015.
Chris Sheppard, general manager of Peter Sheppard Footwear , which turned over $24 million last year, is aware mainstream retailers who compete on price have been pummelled this decade by e-trading rivals.
His business has responded by holding firm to its niche as a shoe fitting company, and its Europe-only stock offering.
"We bring in brands from all over Europe and have no China imports," Sheppard says.
However, acknowledging some of its consumers do expect an online retail option the 42-year-old shoe company will launch its e-commerce platform next April: "It is going to be interesting."
